data:
The 20 rules of formulating knowledge (concise)

Premise
- Learning speed depends heavily on how you formulate what you study. Assume you’re using spaced repetition.

Core rules
1) Don’t learn what you don’t understand
- First ensure comprehension; cramming without understanding is slow and brittle.

2) Learn before you memorize
- Build a simple big-picture model first; then memorize details.

3) Build on basics
- Secure foundational facts; they’re cheap to retain and make new material stick.

4) Minimum information principle
- One fact per item. Short question, shorter answer. Split complex facts.

5) Use cloze deletions
- Turn sentences into fill‑in‑the‑blank items to quickly produce simple prompts.

6) Use imagery
- Prefer diagrams and maps where possible; pictures stick better than words.

7) Use mnemonic techniques
- Pegs, stories, and mind maps help with hard-to-remember items and numbers.

8) Graphic deletions
- Cover parts of an image and recall what’s hidden (great for anatomy, geography).

9) Avoid sets
- Unordered lists are hard; convert to meaningful, ordered sequences or smaller chunks.

10) Avoid enumerations
- If unavoidable, learn with overlapping cloze deletions or grouped chunks.

11) Combat interference
- Make items unambiguous, split similar facts, add cues/examples to distinguish look‑alikes.

12) Optimize wording
- Remove fluff. Keep only what’s needed to trigger the right answer fast.

13) Refer to other memories
- Tie new facts to known concepts to reduce ambiguity and speed recall.

14) Personalize and give examples
- Link to your own experiences; concrete, personal cues cut interference.

15) Use emotion
- Vivid, emotional cues boost recall (without overusing them).

16) Use context cues
- Labels/categories/templates set the frame and reduce confusion (e.g., “bioch: GRE”).

17) Redundancy can help
- Multiple simple views of the same fact (active/passive, steps, synonyms) improve retention.

18) Record sources
- Note where a fact came from to resolve conflicts and update reliably.

19) Date-stamp volatile facts
- Tag figures/versions so you know when to refresh or replace them.

20) Prioritize
- You can’t learn everything; choose sources, extract what matters, set higher retention for high‑value items, and revisit/rewrite or delete low‑value ones.

Quick application checklist
- Stuck item? Split it; make Q shorter and A minimal.
- Similar items clash? Add disambiguating context, examples, or images.
- Long text? Convert to multiple clozes; avoid full-paragraph memorization.
- Lists? Order them, group them, or use overlapping clozes.
- Valuable concept? Store it from multiple angles and include reasoning steps.
- Add source and date for facts likely to change.
- Reprioritize regularly: improve, reschedule, or delete weak or low-value items.
